meaning_mnemonic:
The <radical>height</radical> radical and the <kanji>height</kanji> kanji are the same!

That said, there's a secondary meaning to this kanji of <kanji>ten feet</kanji>. So, when you think of height, think of that height as being ten feet tall.
meaning_hint: If you paid attention in radicals school, you'll be able to learn this kanji meaning easily.
reading_mnemonic: When you think of <kanji>height</kanji>, think of our huge farmhand friend, <reading>Joe</reading> (じょう). He's a big guy, and he has a lot of height to him. In fact, he's <kanji>ten feet</kanji> tall.
reading_hint: Joe really is a big guy. Look up at him, and try to measure him, although ten feet might be a little high for you to reach.

meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>private</radical> <radical>leader</radical> is <kanji>Buddha</kanji>. You don't feel the need to tell everyone. But when you're alone you give your time to Buddha and let him lead your life.
meaning_hint:
Imagine being in the privacy of your own home, your own room, and saying to yourself, "Yes Buddha, you're my leader."

Or, if that irks you, don't. Your religion is your own private right, yo.
reading_mnemonic: Your private <kanji>Buddha</kanji> is a little different than other people's idea of him. Your Buddha is wearing <reading>boots</reading> (ぶつ). They're big and rubber, and they look fabulous on him.
reading_hint: Picture Buddha wearing a giant pair of rubber boots. Yes, now this is fashion.

meaning_mnemonic: You <radical>say</radical> to your <radical>leader</radical>, “<kanji>Believe</kanji> and <kanji>trust</kanji> in me, I’m responsible.” The leader doesn’t think you can handle your duties, so this is why you said this to him. You want him to believe and trust you. You can handle this task.
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself saying this to your leader. Say it out loud as you imagine saying it to a leader of some sort.
reading_mnemonic: To show you are serious as you say, “<kanji>Believe</kanji> and <kanji>trust</kanji> in me, I’m responsible,” you kneel down on each <reading>shin</reading> (しん). You have shin splints, so it hurts a bit, but you do it anyway to show how serious you are.
reading_hint: Picture yourself pleading with your leader to trust and believe in you. Imagine the hurt of your shins with the shin splints as you kneel. It hurts a lot, but it proves how serious you are.

meaning_mnemonic: Take your <radical>yakuza</radical> <radical>knife</radical> and put it in a <kanji>row</kanji> with the others.
meaning_hint: You have a yakuza knife. There are a bunch there, all in a row, so you follow suit by putting yours in the row too.
reading_mnemonic: Should we put them in a <kanji>row</kanji>? <reading>Let's</reading> (れつ) put them in a row!
reading_hint: Imagine a bunch of yakuza being enthusiastic about putting their knives in a row. They all say together "Ret's do it!"

meaning_mnemonic: The radical for <radical>courage</radical> and the kanji for <kanji>courage</kanji> are exactly the same.
meaning_hint: That means if you know your radicals well, you know the meaning of this kanji too!
reading_mnemonic: A man needs <kanji>courage</kanji> to stand up to all the <reading>you</reading>ths (ゆう) of the world. They are so numerous and difficult to understand, but the man can face them with courage thanks to his mama.
reading_hint: Imagine a courageous man standing against the youths. They use weird slang and try to tell him about avocado toast, but the man keeps his courage.

meaning_mnemonic: In the <radical>cage</radical> there are some <radical>legs</radical>. They are the legs attached to a <kanji>small animal</kanji>.
meaning_hint: You can only see the legs, though, because a cloth is covering the cage. What kind of small animal is it? Try to look.
reading_mnemonic: You look up through the cloth, and see a hairless cat. This <kanji>small animal</kanji> is hairless, but most surprisingly is covered in <reading>hickie</reading>s (ひき).
reading_hint: Who is giving this cat all those hickies? Pretty gross, if you ask me.

meaning_mnemonic: This <radical>cage</radical> with <radical>treasure</radical> in it is actually a map of the <kanji>district</kanji> the treasure is in.
meaning_hint: Picture a big pirate map, and on it are a bunch of these markers for the districts where you can find the treasures you've been searching for.
reading_mnemonic: There is one <kanji>district</kanji> you're interested in, and that's the <reading>coo</reading>kie (く) district.
reading_hint: The treasure of the cookie district is cookies, which you want. And to be fair, even if you weren't a pirate, you'd probably want those cookies.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>simple</radical> radical and the <kanji>simple</kanji> kanji are the same!
meaning_hint: Simple is simple!
reading_mnemonic: One of the most <kanji>simple</kanji> things in the world is getting a <reading>tan</reading> (たん). All you have to do is stand outside long enough. It doesn't matter what skin type you have or what the weather is like. Eventually, if you stand out there long enough, you'll get a tan.
reading_hint: Get a tan, it's simple, stupid! (Though it's terrible for you so uh... don't always take our advice, kay?)

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>creeper</radical> inside of a <radical>cape</radical>, who are they? They’re the <kanji>director</kanji> of a movie. They try to look all mysterious, but you know it’s just so people go see their movies and think they’re cool. Really they’re just a creep deep down.
meaning_hint: Picture the creepiest director you know. Wearing a cloak and cackling as he directs your favorite actors.
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>director</kanji> is currently directing a movie about <reading>shee</reading>p (し). He keeps petting them and talking to them like they're humans.
reading_hint: The creep director gets really into whatever his current project is. Picture him wearing a sheep costume with the cape over it, petting and whispering to his sheep cast.

meaning_mnemonic: This is <radical>anti</radical> <radical>dirt</radical>. The dirt is becoming not dirt as it goes on, forming a... <kanji>slope</kanji>! Really what is the air above a slope but anti dirt?
meaning_hint: This is some high level thinking, but I know you can do it. Picture a slope. Now picture an anti slope (like a negative image). It's all just dirt and anti dirt at the same time! Woah! Mind Freak!
reading_mnemonic: You need to know these kinds of things about <kanji>slope</kanji>s if you want to play <reading>soccer</reading> (さか). Soccer is pretty slope-intensive. You really have to know how to read their dirt and anti dirt to really get good.
reading_hint: Picture a slope. Now picture yourself playing soccer on the slope. Now picture your anti self playing soccer on the anti slope.

meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Again</radical> and again, <radical>winter</radical> <kanji>change</kanji>s you each year.
meaning_hint: With every winter that comes around, another year passes, and you change. Again and again. The never ending cycle of winters and change.
reading_mnemonic: You know what else <kanji>change</kanji>s each winter? <reading>Hen</reading>s (へん)! They're constantly laying eggs, which then (possibly) turn into new hens.
reading_hint: Picture you and your hens. Going through change, every winter, again and again.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>husband</radical> radical and the <kanji>husband</kanji> kanji are the same. How useful, unlike some husbands, I'd imagine.
reading_mnemonic: What do all <kanji>husband</kanji>s love? <reading>Foo</reading>d (ふう)! Can you hear your future husband? He’s saying, "Fooooood! FOOOOOD!” like some kind of food craving zombie.
reading_hint: Husbands love eating food. Who doesn’t though, really?

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>temple</radical> radical and the <kanji>temple</kanji> kanji are exactly the same! Brilliant.
reading_mnemonic: Someone died. You ask how this person died, the person who's getting buried by the <kanji>temple</kanji>. The priest/monk says it was in a tragic <reading>terror</reading> (てら) attack.
reading_hint: That's too bad - feel sorry for the person and learn a little more about the terror attack, if it will help you to remember the reading of this kanji better.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>mountain</radical> <radical>stone</radical> is probably going to be a really big stone. We're talking about a <kanji>boulder</kanji> here.
meaning_hint: This kanji makes a lot of sense. Just follow the logic.
reading_mnemonic: "<kanji>Boulder</kanji>!!!" yells a voice from behind you. "<reading>Eek, wha</reading>...?" (いわ) you reply. You look up to see a boulder falling off the cliff above you. "Eeeeeek! Whaaaat!?," you shout again, running and screaming this time.
reading_hint: Imagine yourself screaming "Eeeeeek! Whaaaat!?" and running away from that boulder as fast as you can.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>knife</radical> got stuck in <radical>Wolverine</radical>'s <radical>forehead</radical>, and he has a <radical>towel</radical> wrapped around it to stop the bleeding, but he really needs to <kanji>return home</kanji>.
meaning_hint: Everything is fun and games until someone gets hurt. And in this case, very hurt. If something like this happens, it's always best to return home.
reading_mnemonic: Wolverine wants to <kanji>return home</kanji>, but he can't drive himself because there's a knife in his forehead and lots of blood, so he asks his friend the <reading>ca</reading>r <reading>e</reading>lephant (かえ) to take him. Car elephant is just an elephant mutant that has a car on his back.
reading_hint: Watch as Wolverine climbs up onto car elephant and returns home. Well, this party was a failure.

meaning_mnemonic:
To <radical>construct</radical> a whole <radical>ceremony</radical>, you can’t just make it up on the spot. That is not a ceremony. A ceremony has a past. A ceremony is done a certain way because that’s the way it’s always been done. In short, to build a ceremony, you have to create a <kanji>ritual</kanji> first. Then, the ritual can be constructed into a bigger, more lavish <kanji>ceremony</kanji>.

This kanji also means <kanji>equation</kanji> for some reason. Just think of a ceremony that involves doing math and coming up with equations. How strange would that be? Pretend you're at this ceremony.
meaning_hint: Ritual and ceremony kind of mean the same thing. Don't worry too much if you mix them up a little - each will help you to remember the other. There's a reason this kanji is made up of the ceremony radical already!
reading_mnemonic: So, you're at a <kanji>ritual</kanji>, but not just any old ritual. This is a full-blown <kanji>ceremony</kanji> and it's incredibly <reading>chic</reading> (しき). Imagine just how chic it is. Give it a shot – I'll let you come up with the chicness this time (it's good practice).
reading_hint: It's good to practice making your own mnemonics up every once in a while. It'll help you to add on to the mnemonics already here and make better ones more personal to yourself!

meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>fingers</radical> are <radical>private</radical>, no one can see them unless they <kanji>pay</kanji>! And you decide if what they pay is enough to get a peek.
meaning_hint: Imagine people coming from miles around to pay for a look at your private fingers.
reading_mnemonic: If someone tries to look without paying, that's <reading>hara</reading>ssment (はら)! Nobody gets to see something of yours without proper payment, but more importantly, your consent!
reading_hint: If somebody looks at your fingers without paying, without your consent, file a harassment claim on their butt! That is NOT okay!

meaning_mnemonic: You can <radical>branch</radical> out your <radical>fingers</radical>. It's your special <kanji>skill</kanji> that requires some good <kanji>technique</kanji>s. Your fingers branch out into smaller fingers and you can hold things really well. You can type super-duper fast. And you can win any tickle fight. These are skills you have thanks to your branching fingers.
meaning_hint: If you could have any skill imaginable, what would it be? Wouldn't it be nice to have these magical branching fingers? (Definitely. It would.)
reading_mnemonic: Unfortunately, these <kanji>skill</kanji>s are too much for the normal skill-less people to handle and they pull out the <reading>gui</reading>llotine (ぎ). I guess they're going to chop off your skillful fingers because they're kinda scary.
reading_hint: Imagine a tiny guillotine made for the cutting of fingers. Whoever made this must have had special hand skills too! Maybe they tested it on them...

meaning_mnemonic: When you see the <radical>spring</radical> <radical>sun</radical> you know it's finally the  <kanji>spring</kanji> season.
meaning_hint: The spring sun only comes out in spring, which is why you know for sure it's spring. Imagine a different looking sun that only comes out in spring but not the other seasons.
reading_mnemonic: When the <kanji>spring</kanji> season comes around, it makes you want to laugh: "<reading>HAR</reading> (はる) HAR HAR!" you yell.
reading_hint: Go ahead and belt out a few "HAR HAR HARs" for spring. It's warming up, everything is coming to life, and you're happy. "HAR HAR HAR!"

meaning_mnemonic: With the right <radical>key</radical> you can unlock the <radical>sun</radical> to <kanji>yesterday</kanji>, or a <kanji>previous</kanji> day. The sun is in charge of the day changes, so if you use a key to unlock it, you can control the flow of time and return to yesterday, or a previous day in the past. Behold the power of the sun.
meaning_hint: Imagine having the power to control time like this. Picture yourself unlocking the sun to go back in time. Feel the heat of the sun and the bright light in your eyes as you unlock the door to the past.
reading_mnemonic: Time traveling to a <kanji>previous</kanji> time, like <kanji>yesterday</kanji>, can be rough on the body. As such, you wear a small <reading>sack</reading> (さく) to hold your valuables while you’re ripped through the sands of time. The sack keeps your important stuff from getting lost. The sack holds your key to the sun as well.
reading_hint: Imagine wearing this sack as you’re sucked through the vortex of time and space. Feel yourself spinning around as you hurtle back into yesterday.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>sun</radical> rises from the <radical>ground</radical>, and on top of it is a giant <radical>shrimp</radical>. It doesn't do anything except for every day right at <kanji>noon</kanji>, when it tells you the time. "Hey guyz, it's <kanji>noon</kanji>, mmk?"
meaning_hint: Really try to imagine this giant shrimp on the sun as a normal thing that happens, without fail, every day. The shrimp also tells the time right at noon, every day (so important you stress remembering that it's noon, not some other time). Maybe you could have him sing a "noon song" in your imagination as well.
reading_mnemonic: At <kanji>noon</kanji>, the shrimp also puts on its high <reading>heel</reading>s (ひる) to get ready for the evening, where it wants to make sure it looks good for the other shrimp he/she meets later on.
reading_hint: Right after the shrimp's announcement, imagine it struggling to put on heels, while sitting on the sun. This shrimp is almost bigger than the sun, actually, so all its struggles with its heels are easy to see.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>sun</radical> has an <radical>excuse</radical> for disappearing at <kanji>night</kanji>. The sun gets really tired, same as anyone else – so when night rolls around the sun excuses itself and goes to sleep. It’s a valid excuse.
meaning_hint: Imagine you’re the sun, working all day. Of course you get tired. This is a good excuse to go to bed at night and get some rest. Feel how sore and hot and sweaty and exhausted you are after a hard day’s work of being the sun.
reading_mnemonic: Unfortunately, you also have a history of overworking yourself, so you've been outright <reading>ban</reading>ned (ばん) from showing up at <kanji>night</kanji>.
reading_hint: Stop working so much! Humans need some rest too, so it can't always be bright. Maybe you should try some therapy. We all just want to see you get better, sun. Anyway, you're banned for now. Cya.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>sun</radical> is out, the sky is <radical>blue</radical>, things have begun to <kanji>clear up</kanji>!
meaning_hint: Look into the blue sky and imagine the clouds parting as the weather clears up and you can see the sun. Gorgeous! The beauty is so great you have to squint.
reading_mnemonic: Now that it's starting to <kanji>clear up</kanji> you can't help but laugh. "<reading>Ha</reading> (は)! Ha ha ha!" you laugh up into the sky. The sun feels great on your face, making you feel lively! And that blue sky ain't too shabby either.
reading_hint: Say the "ha ha ha" part out loud while you imagine the weather clearing up. It'll help you to remember the reading of this kanji.

meaning_mnemonic: To throw <radical>life</radical> out the <radical>window</radical>, use <kanji>poison</kanji>.
meaning_hint: To keep life safely inside the window, put that poison down.
reading_mnemonic: If anything's worse than <kanji>poison</kanji> it's doing Su<reading>doku</reading> (どく) puzzles.
reading_hint: Have you done Sudoku before? Imagine yourself completing these puzzles and concentrating really hard. They’re fun, but also challenging.

meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Tsunami</radical>s in the <radical>past</radical> changed the <kanji>method</kanji>s and <kanji>law</kanji>s of today.
meaning_hint: Tsunamis used to come crashing into towns, just leveling them completely. Today we have new methods of building and protecting ourselves, and laws to keep them in place, so the past doesn't repeat itself.
reading_mnemonic: These <kanji>method</kanji>s and <kanji>law</kanji>s affected your own <reading>ho</reading>me (ほう) the most.
reading_hint: Your home has strong walls and ceilings. You aren't allowed to leave the doors unlocked and open. These methods and laws are because of those past tsunamis and the damage they used to cause. Your home is safe thanks to them!

meaning_mnemonic: If you <radical>stand</radical> in front of a <radical>tsunami</radical>, you’re going to <kanji>cry</kanji>. That tsunami is going to hit you hard, and rip you right off the ground on which you stand. Who wouldn't cry?
meaning_hint: Imagine getting hit with the full force of a tsunami. It slams into you and crushes every bone in your body. It hurts so much you cry.
reading_mnemonic: Do you know the only way to stop yourself <kanji>cry</kanji>ing after a tsunami? That's right, <reading>na</reading>chos (な)! Nachos are the only proven way to cheer people up after being hit by a tsunami.
reading_hint: Imagine stuffing yourself with nachos. The tears stop. You're feeling bruised and wet, but much better.

meaning_mnemonic: If you visit a <radical>bar</radical> after a <radical>tsunami</radical>, you’ll be hanging out in <kanji>shallow</kanji> water. After a tsunami, you want to relax with a drink at the bar. Unfortunately, tsunamis cause floods, and the bar floor is immersed in shallow water.
meaning_hint: Picture yourself at this bar, sipping on a drink while you’re wading in this shallow water. Feel the shallow water getting your socks and shoes all wet. It’s uncomfortable and cold.
reading_mnemonic: What beer are you drinking at this bar while standing in <kanji>shallow</kanji> water? You’re drinking <reading>Asa</reading>hi (あさ), the beer of the salaryman. Asahi is super dry, so it takes your attention away from the shallow water a bit.
reading_hint: Picture yourself in the bar again sipping on this Asahi beer. Taste the beery beer taste of Asahi as you walk around the bar with your wet feet.

meaning_mnemonic: If you see an <radical>animal</radical> among the <radical>flowers</radical> in a <radical>rice paddy</radical>, chances are it’s a <kanji>cat</kanji>. Cats love rice paddy flowers, almost as much as they love catnip.
meaning_hint: Picture this cat meowing and purring as it rubs up against all the flowers in the rice paddy field. Aww, it’s so cute!
reading_mnemonic: Wait a minute… This <kanji>cat</kanji> is pretty odd looking. You take a closer look, seeing it is missing its <reading>neck</reading> (ねこ). You go to pet it, but it's super sensitive about that area of its head, which is basically a face connected to a body...
reading_hint: Try not to imagine this too hard. It is disturbing.

meaning_mnemonic: When a <radical>spirit</radical> decides to live in your <radical>scarecrow</radical>, you'll be granted good <kanji>luck</kanji> and good <kanji>fortune</kanji>. Crows won't hang out in your farm. Everything you grow will become large and delicious. But not everyone is so lucky that a spirit will decide to live in their scarecrow. So maybe the luck was in you all along!
meaning_hint: Nope, the luck is definitely coming from the spirit in your scarecrow. You aren't lucky on your own.
reading_mnemonic: You want to check the scarecrow to make sure your recent <kanji>luck</kanji> is coming from it, so you kick it. "<reading>F***</reading> (ふく) you!" it yells. Oh yeah, there's a spirit in there.
reading_hint: If you get a luck spirit to say f*** you, you might accidentally convince it to move somewhere else. If it does, you lose your luck. So be careful.

meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Grain</radical>s look like they're on <radical>fire</radical> in <kanji>autumn</kanji>. They all turn red and orange and brown, the colors of fire. It's also fun to set grains on fire in Autumn, since it's getting colder.
meaning_hint: Picture all the grains in autumn. Picture all of the colors. The colors of fire.
reading_mnemonic: As the grains burn, and the season changes to autumn, imagine them yelling out in pain: "<reading>ACK</reading> (あき)!"
reading_hint:
Ah yes, the sound of the seasons changing to autumn.

Ack!
Ack!
Ack!

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>thread</radical> you weave together to tell others about <radical>oneself</radical> is the <kanji>account</kanji> of your life. It's your very own <kanji>narrative</kanji>, tying everything you've been through together.
meaning_hint: Picture this account of your life, the thread of the narrative linking all of the different important points in your life together.
reading_mnemonic: You take this <kanji>account</kanji> and lock it with a special <reading>key</reading> (き). You only give this key to people you really trust, so they can read the account of your life and truly understand you.
reading_hint: Picture the people in your life that you'd give this special key to. They'd get to read the account of your life, so make sure they're trustworthy before you hand that key over.

meaning_mnemonic:
There are many <radical>flowers</radical> in the <radical>center</radical> of <kanji>England</kanji>. It may seem rainy and gray at first, but if you walk right to the center you'll see all the flowers that grow there in the center of the country.

This kanji also means <kanji>English</kanji>, which is pretty similar to England. Just imagine all the people of England walking to the center, where the flowers are, and speaking English to them to help them grow.
meaning_hint: Picture yourself in the center of England, speaking English to all of the beautiful flowers.
reading_mnemonic: You keep walking to the very central center of <kanji>England</kanji> and see a giant <reading>a</reading>corn (えい) planted in the middle of the ground. This acorn is the source of all the flowers and life in England.
reading_hint: Imagine walking around the giant English acorn. Touch its smooth surface with your hand.

meaning_mnemonic: There <radical>go</radical> some <radical>angel</radical>s with <radical>drop</radical>s on their shoulders. Carrying drops like that requires <kanji>technique</kanji>. It’s a real <kanji>art</kanji>.
meaning_hint: Angels are really good at going around carrying drops! Imagine the artistry and technique involved. I bet they do some kind of dance, and there's lots of sparkly magic.
reading_mnemonic: Angels are so good at this because they are trained in nin<reading>jutsu</reading> (じゅつ), or the "ninja techniques." Everyone knows that ninjas are great at carrying drops on the go!
reading_hint: Imagine an angel trained in ninjutsu. Marvel at all their divine ninja techniques!

meaning_mnemonic: If you want to <radical>say</radical> how big a <radical>cross</radical> is, you have to <kanji>measure</kanji> it. You can't say the size of something without measuring it first.
meaning_hint: Imagine trying to use your hands to show the size of this cross, but the other person shakes their head and says, "Use your words!" Ugh, okay, you'll have to measure it then.
reading_mnemonic: You need to <kanji>measure</kanji> this cross but all you have is a <reading>ca</reading>ke (けい). Good enough! I'm sure all cakes are exactly the same size, so they're a reliable unit of measure.
reading_hint: "This cross measures two cakes wide and three cakes long," you say.

meaning_mnemonic: You run into someone's <radical>forehead</radical> with your <radical>car</radical>. The big forehead you hit is Kim Jong Un's. You know that now you're going to have the whole North Korean <kanji>army</kanji> coming after you.
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself running away from the North Korean army. You have to get to the border, the entire army is coming after you for hitting their dear leader!
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>army</kanji> is after you. Each army soldier has a <reading>gun</reading> (ぐん) and they want to use these guns of theirs to shoot you dead! You killed their leader with a car and now they’re gonna get you back with a gun!
reading_hint: Picture yourself running away from them as they shout and shoot at you. Hear the bullets wizzing past your head as you run away as fast as you can.

meaning_mnemonic: If you're <radical>anti</radical>-<radical>eat</radical> your <kanji>meal</kanji> will just sit in front of you, uneaten. Food is meant to be eaten! Stop trying to fast and take a bite.
meaning_hint: Look down at the huge meal in front of you. I guess there are plenty of reasons to be anti-eat right now, but you'll have to eat your food eventually.
reading_mnemonic: As you stare at the <kanji>meal</kanji>, <reading>Han</reading> (はん) Solo appears before you and takes a bite! This is what happens if you don't eat your food, someone else will eat it.
reading_hint: Picture Han Solo slowly eating your whole meal! He's making constant eye contact with you, reaching down and shoving the entire meal into his mouth.
